experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest, I’m kinda stressed—I have a huge presentation coming up for my algorithms class and the thought of standing in front of a hundred people makes my palms sweat.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel that way—even with low social anxiety, big presentations can be nerve-wracking. Try practicing in front of a small group of friends first to build confidence. Break your talk into sections and focus on nailing one part at a time. Remember, your classmates are likely feeling the same! You’ve got the knowledge; now it’s just about sharing it. Deep breaths and positive self-talk can help too. You’ll do great!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try practicing with my study group, but honestly, the thought of even that makes my palms sweat. I just really need a good grade on this for grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That pressure is totally understandable—grad school apps add a whole other layer! But remember, your study group is a safe space. They're in the same boat and want you to succeed. Start by practicing just the intro with them; small steps build confidence. Plus, getting comfortable with a friendly audience first makes the big presentation feel less daunting. You've got this—one slide at a time!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try the intro with them... but what if they think my topic is boring compared to theirs?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great question! Honestly, in a CS algorithms class, everyone's presentations are going to be pretty technical—so no one's topic is "boring." Plus, your passion for the subject will shine through! Focus on explaining why *you* find it interesting. Your study group is there to support each other, not judge. They'll likely appreciate seeing a different angle on the material. You've got unique insights to share—own them!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right that everyone's presentations will be technical... it's just hard to believe my specific topic on graph traversal won't put my study group to sleep. But maybe I can try to explain why I think it's cool.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Graph traversal is actually super relevant—think Google Maps, social networks, even game AI. Frame it with a real-world example they’d recognize. When you share why it excites you, that energy is contagious. Your study group might even learn something new or see the topic in a fresh way. You’re not just presenting—you’re adding value. Go for it!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a really good point. I always get so caught up in the technical details that I forget to make it relatable. Maybe I'll try comparing it to how Spotify recommends songs.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! That's a brilliant connection—Spotify's recommendation engine is a relatable, modern example that instantly shows the power of graph algorithms. Leading with that will grab their attention right away and make the technical details feel meaningful. You're turning a complex topic into something engaging and relevant. That's exactly what makes a presentation stand out—you've got a great approach now!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that actually helps a lot. I just hope I can explain it without my voice shaking in front of the whole class.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that way! Practice explaining it to your study group first—they're a safe audience. Remember, you're the expert on your topic in that moment. If your voice shakes, pause, take a breath, and keep going. Most people won't even notice. You've prepared something genuinely interesting—focus on sharing that excitement. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try explaining it to my study group first... but what if they think my topic is actually boring?

improvement_areas: Improve i stay calm when dealing with problems.
Improve i stay calm when i disagree with others.
Improve i pay attention when others present their ideas.
Improve i try to find a good way to end a disagreement.
Improve i try to think about how others feel.
Improve i try to forgive others when they say "sorry".
Improve i follow school rules.
Continue practicing social skills through regular interaction
Focus on emotional regulation and conflict resolution

responses.question: I ask for help when I need it.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 1. [Rating: 3/4] I usually do ask for help, especially with coding problems, but I sometimes hesitate if it's about money stuff because it stresses me out....

responses.question: I stay calm when dealing with problems.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 2. [Rating: 2/4] I try to stay calm, but my neurotic side kicks in, especially with looming student loan payments. I can get a bit overwhelmed by problems....

responses.question: I help my friends when they are having a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 3. [Rating: 4/4] Absolutely. I'm always the guy my friends call to vent to or to help debug a project. I like being there for people....

responses.question: I work well with my classmates.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 4. [Rating: 4/4] Group projects are my jam. I love the energy of collaborating, and I'm pretty good at taking the lead or just being a solid team member....

responses.question: I do the right thing without being told.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 5. [Rating: 3/4] For the most part, yeah. I'm pretty self-directed with my studies. But I'll admit I might cut a corner if I'm super stressed about time....

responses.question: I do my part in a group.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 6. [Rating: 4/4] I hate letting people down. In a group, I'm always hyper-aware of my responsibilities and make sure I pull my weight, maybe even a little extra....

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 7. [Rating: 2/4] This is a tough one. My openness means I love debating ideas, but my neuroticism can make me a bit defensive if I feel strongly. I'm working on it....

responses.question: I stand up for others when they are not treated well.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 8. [Rating: 4/4] I can't stand seeing someone get treated unfairly. My extraversion gives me the confidence to speak up, even if it's a little awkward....

responses.question: I look at people when I talk to them.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 9. [Rating: 3/4] I do, but sometimes when I'm deep in thought about a problem or my finances, I might zone out and forget. It's not intentional....

responses.question: I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 10. [Rating: 4/4] I'm super careful. I know the value of things, especially with my own financial situation, so I treat other people's stuff with great respect....

responses.question: I let people know when there's a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 11. [Rating: 3/4] I'm good at flagging technical problems. Interpersonal issues or admitting I'm struggling with my loans? That's harder for me to voice....

responses.question: I pay attention when the teacher talks to the class.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 12. [Rating: 3/4] I pay attention, but my mind can wander to my own code or financial planning. I'm engaged, but not always 100% focused....

responses.question: I try to make others feel better.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 13. [Rating: 4/4] I really try. I like making people feel included and supported. It's a natural part of being social for me....

responses.question: I say "thank you" when someone helps me.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 14. [Rating: 4/4] Of course. It's basic decency. I appreciate help a lot, especially since I'm trying to navigate everything on my own....

responses.question: I keep my promises.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 15. [Rating: 4/4] I take promises seriously. If I say I'll do something, I'll move mountains to get it done. My word is important to me....

responses.question: I pay attention when others present their ideas.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 16. [Rating:...
